Where y t is the number of cases of malformation divided by the number of births multiplied by 100000 (rate) in each month; T t is the time since the start of the study; X t is a dummy variable that was 0 if the birth date was before Sept 2015 or 1 otherwise; X tT t is the interaction between the time and the dummy variable[ 20]. We use this model to estimate four parameters: (i) β
0 that is the rate of malformation at T 0 (“Pre-zika starting level”), (ii) β
1 the mean increase in the malformation rate monthly before Sept 2015 (“Pre Zika event”), (iii) β
2 is a change in the slope after Sept 2015 (immediately change) and (iv) β
3 the mean increase in malformation rate after Sept 2015 (“Post Zika event”). Furthermore, for each β estimated in our model a t-test is performed to check the parameter values is equal to 0. We assumed that any time-varying unmeasured confounder is relatively slowly changing so that it would be distinguishable from the sharp jump of the event indicator (Zika epidemic).
